component.description: The menuList component creates a series of navigation items representing one level in a navigation hierarchy.

property.description:
The style of the list. Defaults to disc. Options are:
  • disc
  • circle
  • square
  • decimal
  • lowerAlpha
  • upperAlpha
  • none
Please keep in mind that the letters used for upperAlpha and lowerAlpha are the 26 letters of the English language, which may lead to translation problems.

property-extension.mfp:property-values: decimal square none circle lowerAlpha upperAlpha disc

component-extension.mfp:long-description:
<html:p> The menuList component creates a series of navigation items representing one level in a navigation hierarchy. These items may either be added as children or a menu model may be bound to the menuList component. If a menu model is bound, of class <html:code>org.apache.myfaces.trinidad.model.MenuModel</html:code>, a level along the focus path, or the next level down, will be rendered. A node that is on the focus path will be rendered as "selected". </html:p> <html:p> The 'level' attribute is used to indicate the level along the focusPath to render. </html:p> <html:p> MenuModel extends TreeModel, but it also knows how to go from the current viewId to the focus path. Notice that the menuModel has no special knowledge of page navigation and places no requirements on the nodes that go into the tree. The nodes in the tree are stamped out with the 'nodeStamp' facet, which should contain a commandNavigationItem component, which allows the default actionListener mechanism to be used for page navigation. </html:p>
<section name="Supported Attributes"> <html:p> The menuList component can render a bullet, circle, square, lower case letter, upper case letter, or number next to each item. The "listStyle" attribute indicates which style of list to render. Defaults to disc. Options are: <html:ul> <html:li>disc </html:li> <html:li>circle </html:li> <html:li>square </html:li> <html:li>decimal </html:li> <html:li>lowerAlpha </html:li> <html:li>upperAlpha </html:li> <html:li>none </html:li> </html:ul> Please keep in mind that the letters used for upperAlpha and lowerAlpha are the 26 letters of the English language, which may lead to translation problems. </html:p>
</section>
